posts.subject: /ALPR/ GENERAL 0.2 (zeronet version=
posts.body:
Sup guys, I thought I'd never get to speak to you again. I'm going to update this thread with the info gathered earlier and see if we can work on some diy solutions using the products described. 


<LET'S DO SOME INFOSEC WORK SHAZBOTS

This is a new series I am going to make based on the products collectively known as Automatic License Plate Readers (aka ALPRs). There is a lot of mystery and myth surrounding this technology as well as methods of effectively evading it, if any exist at all. Collectively I am confident we can find a solution to the Automated threat 

>inb4 if you have nothing to hide you have nothing to fear

Fuck you. 

>What is it?

"Typically, ALPR systems are comprised of high-speed cameras connected to computers that photograph every license plate that passes. The photo is converted to letters and numbers, which are attached to a time and location stamp, then uploaded to a central server.  This allows police to identify and record the locations of vehicles in real time and also identify where those vehicles have been in the past. Using this information, police could establish driving patterns for individual cars. The type of data ALPRs collect, analyze, and access often depends on what kind of systems they use and how they combine the data."

https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/04/four-flavors-automated-license-plate-reader-technology 

( https://web.archive.org/web/20190705211401/https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/04/four-flavors-automated-license-plate-reader-technology )

>Why the concern?

Much like Stringrays (cell towerspoofing MITM devices used by LEO) a few years back, these devices are essentially unregulated. When used by private parties have been they have been able to scan up to 8k license plates in a single day, according to only one study. These databases are up for sale, much like cell location data. The data recorded includes GPS location, scan coordinates, and timestamp. When factoring in this information and without even the consideration of data breaches this clearly becomes an issue to everyone's privacy.

https://www.popsci.com/article/technology/scan-artist/

( https://web.archive.org/web/20190616105746/https://www.popsci.com/article/technology/scan-artist/ )

>Okay shazbot, what can we do about it?

I'm not sure yet, that's what I'm hoping our collective effort can discover. Below I will list some of the methods tried, there viability, cost, and feasibility.

Template Pastebin:

https://pastebin.com/u0xaeu9P

posts.subject: /ALPR/ GENERAL 0.2 (zeronet mirror)
posts.body:
I created a thread on /cy/ as well,  mistaking the single users multiple posts as organic content. I can maintain two threads I think. We'll see. I'll be posting proposes solutions here as well. 

<LET'S DO SOME INFOSEC WORK SHAZBOTS

This is a new series I am going to make based on the products collectively known as Automatic License Plate Readers (aka ALPRs). There is a lot of mystery and myth surrounding this technology as well as methods of effectively evading it, if any exist at all. Collectively I am confident we can find a solution to the Automated threat 

>inb4 if you have nothing to hide you have nothing to fear

Fuck you. 

>What is it?

"Typically, ALPR systems are comprised of high-speed cameras connected to computers that photograph every license plate that passes. The photo is converted to letters and numbers, which are attached to a time and location stamp, then uploaded to a central server.  This allows police to identify and record the locations of vehicles in real time and also identify where those vehicles have been in the past. Using this information, police could establish driving patterns for individual cars. The type of data ALPRs collect, analyze, and access often depends on what kind of systems they use and how they combine the data."

https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/04/four-flavors-automated-license-plate-reader-technology 

( https://web.archive.org/web/20190705211401/https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/04/four-flavors-automated-license-plate-reader-technology )

>Why the concern?

Much like Stringrays (cell towerspoofing MITM devices used by LEO) a few years back, these devices are essentially unregulated. When used by private parties have been they have been able to scan up to 8k license plates in a single day, according to only one study. These databases are up for sale, much like cell location data. The data recorded includes GPS location, scan coordinates, and timestamp. When factoring in this information and without even the consideration of data breaches this clearly becomes an issue to everyone's privacy.

https://www.popsci.com/article/technology/scan-artist/

( https://web.archive.org/web/20190616105746/https://www.popsci.com/article/technology/scan-artist/ )

>Okay shazbot, what can we do about it?

I'm not sure yet, that's what I'm hoping our collective effort can discover. Below I will list some of the methods tried, there viability, cost, and feasibility.

Template Pastebin:

https://pastebin.com/u0xaeu9P
This is a good idea,  sort of like those html to email fetches. As there is an Android app it could even be accomplished with an old phone. Nice.

Here's a link to the old site on webarchive: 
https://web.archive.org/web/20190801221429/https://8ch.net/cyber/res/56702.html#q56800

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mJ6rLhkZ3Hg

This is probably the best solution found so far. It's a film that changes opacity based on an electronic current. 


https://www.endlessparts.com/collections/smart-film

>>5fbaa0c4-6b31-4e95-8230-f105f1665676

This is a good suggestion and something I'd recommend for anyone practicing good OpSec. However, avoidance isnt the goal here. Overcoming or bypassing these systems is. 

>>cf0e2699-f2b1-4756-adc9-90179e56f97c this also raises concerns about cycling as transportation. Do they have plates or do they just use their faces? 

>>fd490b5e-c7fa-4cd2-9470-e8a037600242 I totally agree. I plan on migrating here permanently. Zeronet really needed a catalyst to increase its popularity due to the very nature of it and now we have that. I'd encourage anyone who's capable to try and contribute to the source code on github. It's written in python so it's a great beginners project. I'm going to start messing with it myself after I get some bearings in it. It's a cool idea and I want to support the community.  https://github.com/HelloZeroNet?tab=repositories

Also, don't forget there are other sites here. Use Kaffiene, a Zeronet search engine, to help you:http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffiene.bit/
I'm thinking of using Zeronet for a git repo,  similar to this: 
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MCfWoCtcbPXYc3rhYhKeSAWVpzAQYyWKS

>>ea83913d-ad9a-49b7-a9bc-e18582365e29
Haha haha Lmfao what a crazy turn of events.

>>43ccc02e-a88d-4dce-8e45-3d36344e43e7
Damn I cannot wait for this congressional hearing. It's going to be hilarious. I can't believe we live in a timeline where admin of basket weaving forum is going to have to talk to a diverse congress in an occupied formerly white nation about harboring ebil Nazis.

>>e65979fa-51b5-4874-831d-9f8e9dcd1205
This will never work. They need users on TOR to hide there agents in the field. That's the whole point. If anything,  it will just be used as an escalation of crimes after someone is flagged for being a 'nazi'.

>>e65979fa-51b5-4874-831d-9f8e9dcd1205

posts.subject: Which one of you was this?
posts.body:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hitler-Ransomware

>Hitler-Ransomware, or Hitler-Ransonware (sic), is a form of ransomware created in 2016 originating in Germany. It requests payment within one hour; otherwise, it will delete files from the infected computer.

Jonathan (Jessica) Yaniv
Someone I know has been take down this assholes blog all day. They're behind cloudflare of course, I can't find any leaked domains, but I did find an Xss injection in one of the plug-ins but um reaching the limits of my abilities.I've tried Ghost Scanner, pingback, and xmlrpc login but I think I'm hitting the wrong IP.

Any help would be appreciated!
Sorry about the post quality I'm very tired.
